Atsushi Satsuma, Tadashi Hattori*, Yuichi Murakami Department of Applied Chemistry, Nagoya University, Chikusa, Nagoya 464-01, Japan (Received 24 August 1993, revised manuscript received 5 November 1993 ) Abstract The effect of the acidic property of support materials on the activity of a platinum catalyst in the low-temperature catalytic combustion of propane was examined by using a series of single metal oxides, mixed oxides and S04--doped oxides as the support materials. It was revealed that the catalytic activity strongly depends on the acidic property of the support materials: the activity is higher on the support having stronger acidity. S04--doped oxides, known as solid superacids, are superior support materials giving high activity at low temperatures. Key words: acid strength; catalytic combustion; low-temperature catalytic combustion; platinum; solid superacid; support effect 1. Introduction Although automotive exhaust catalysts are widely used for the reduction of emission levels, there is still a great deal of room for further improvements [ I ] . One of the future tasks will be the improvement of the catalytic activity for low-temperature catalytic combustion because most of the hydrocarbons emitted from automotive exhaust are generated in the initial warmup period of the catalyst. It is widely accepted that precious metals such as platinum and palladium are the most active catalyst ingredients for catalytic combustion [2-6]. The catalytic property of precious metals is also well known to be remarkably modified by using proper support materials in many catalytic reactions. However, the effect of support materials on low-temperature catalytic combustion has not been examined, except that the activity of a supported platinum catalyst in the combustion of methane was reported to be in the order of Pt/Si02 - A1203 > Pt/A1203 > Pt1Si02 [7 ] . *Corresponding author.Fax. Experimental The catalysts used in the present study were platinum catalysts supported on a series of single and mixed oxides and solid superacids as shown in Table 1. A1203, Ti02, Si02 and S'Oz - A1203 are the reference catalysts of the Catalysis Society of Japan [ 8,9 ] . The other single metal oxides are commercially supplied guaranteed reagents, and the other mixed oxides prepared by sol-mixing method were supplied from Nikki Chemicals Co. Ltd. Solid superacids were prepared according to the methods described in the literature. S04--Zr02 was obtained by immersing a fine powder of Zr(OH)4 on a filter paper in 0.5 M HZSOc followed by drying and calcining at 798 K for 3 h. Zr(OH)4 was obtained by hydrolyzing 2 ZrOCl2 - 8H20 with aqueous ammonia followed by washing and drying [ 10] .50--A1203 was obtained by immersing a fine powder of A1203 (JRC-ALO-4) in 1.25 M HZSOc followed by drying and calcining at 873 K for 3 h [ 11 ] . Support materials thus obtained were sieved to + 28--48 mesh. The catalyst was pretreated in a flow of O2+N2 mixture (OZ/NZ= 1 /4) at 823 K for 2 h before use. The BET surface area of the support oxide was measured through N2 adsorption at liquid nitrogen temperature by using conventional flow-type adsorption apparatus. The acid strength of the support was measured through the changes in colour of Hammett indicators adsorbed on the support which had been precalcined at 773 K for 3 h. The dispersion of platinum was measured through the pulse-adsorption of CO in a flow of the carrier gas (He) [ 8,9 ] . After the catalyst was reduced in flowing HZ at 673 K, CO pulses were injected at 2 min intervals at room temperature, until the quantity of the exit CO pulse reached a steady value. It was confirmed that CO adsorption on the support materials could be neglected under the conditions used except for Ce02. The dispersion of platinum was calculated from the total CO uptake by assuming a stoichiometry of [CO] /Pts= 1. Total CO uptake by this method has been confirmed to agree well with the amount of chemisorbed CO measured by the conventional static method [ 8,9 ] . Catalytic test was conducted by using a conventional continuous flow reaction apparatus. A small amount of catalyst (0.1 g) was dispersed in 1.0 g of fused alumina particles to prevent a local increase of temperature, and packed in a Pyrex glass tube with an inside diameter of 10 mm at the center of which a glass tube with an outside diameter of 5 mm was installed to cover the thermocouple. The reactor was installed in an electrically heated fluidized sand bath in order to heat the catalyst bed uniformly. The partial pressures of propane and oxygen were 1 and 20 kPa, respectively, with a nitrogen balance, and the total flow rate was 150 cm; (STP) min'. The reaction temperature was raised every 50 K from 473 K to 773 K, and at each temperature reaction products were analyzed 30 min after the bed temperature attained predetermined value. 3. Results and discussion 3.1. Activity of platinum catalysts supported on single metal oxides Fig. 1 shows the activities of platinum catalysts supported on a series of metal oxides as a function of reaction temperature. In all cases, carbon dioxide was the sole reaction product containing carbon atoms. As shown, the catalytic activity of the platinum metal strongly depends on the support materials. The conversion of propane was ca. 60 and 100% at 623 and 773 K, respectively, on the Pt/Si02 catalyst which is the most active of the platinum catalysts supported on single oxides, while Pt/La203 gave only ca. 1 and 15% conversion, respectively, under the same reaction conditions. The activities are in the order of Pt/ Si02 > Pt/A1203 = Pt/Ti02 = Pt/Ce02 > Pt/Zr02 > Pt/La203. This activity pattern is similar to the order of acid strength of the support oxide shown in Table 1: Ti02 > Si02 > Zr02 > La203, though Pt/Si02 seems to form the exception. The support also has an effect on the dispersion of the platinum metal, as shown in Table 1. The dispersion was relatively high on a support with a high BET surface area such as S'OZ and Alz033, and vice versa. One might suspect that the dependence of the catalytic activity on the support oxide may be caused by the difference in dispersion, because the O A. However, the support seems to have an intrinsic effect on the activity of the platinum catalyst because the difference in activity is much larger than that in the dispersion of platinum. The conversion on Pt/Si02 was higher by a factor of 60 than that on Pt/La203 at 623 K, while the dispersion was only higher by a factor of less than 6. 3.2. Activity of platinum catalysts supported on strongly acidic supports The activity pattern mentioned above seems to suggest that the catalytic activity of platinum catalysts depends on the acid-base property of the support oxide because the activity is higher on an acidic support such as Si02, and lower on a basic support such as La203, This supposition led us to expect that the activity of the platinum catalysts could be enhanced by using a support having a strong acidity and to test platinum catalysts supported on a series of mixed oxides and SOQ- -doped oxides. Mixed oxides such as Si02 - A1203, S'Oz - Ti02 and Si02 - Zr02 are said to have a strong acidity [ 12 ] , and the high activity of 2 Pt/Si02 -A1203 was confirmed in the catalytic combustion of methane [7]. S04--doped oxides such as 504--Zr02 [ 10] and SOQ--Al20-3 [ 11 ] are known as solid superacids [12]. Fig. 2 shows the results on these catalysts. As shown, the conversions of propane on most of these catalysts were higher than those on platinum catalysts supported on single oxides shown in Fig. 1. Platinum supported on SO a- -doped oxides, especially, exhibited very high activity: the conversion attained 50% at 523 K, which is lower by ca. 100 K than that on Pt/S'02- Of the mixed oxides used as the support, Si02 - A1203, having the strongest acidity, exhibited the highest conversion while the platinum catalyst supported on Si02 - ZnO, which has only a moderate acid strength, exhibited the lowest catalytic activity of the catalysts shown in Fig. 2. In Fig. 3, the conversion of propane at 523 and 623 K was plotted against the acid strength of the support materials.
